questions.text: Following splint is used in case of
questions.solution:
Image shows aeroplane splint which is used in the treatment of brachial plexus injury (Erb’s palsy).

  • Shoulder is maintained in abduction and external rotation
  • Elbow – Either in flexion or extention
  • Forearm – supination
  • Wrist – extension

questions.text: The sign given below is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The given image has the characteristic wrist sign i.e. the distal phalange of the first and fifth fingers of the hand overlaps when wrapped around the opposite wrist. This is seen in Marfan's syndrome. This happens as their fingers and hands are long and slender and have a spider-like appearance (arachnodactyly). 

Marfan's syndrome is an inherited connective tissue disorder that is caused by a mutation in a gene that codes for an extracellular matrix protein-fibrillin-1 (FBN1). The FBN1 locus is on the long arm of chromosome 15. It is a clinical diagnosis based on skeletal, cardiovascular, and ocular manifestations. 

Skeletal manifestations: 

  • Overgrowth of long bones (dolichostenomelia) with an arm span to height ratio of more than 1.05
  • Pectus carinatum or pectus excavatum
  • Long and slender fingers (arachnodactyly), contracture of fingers (camptodactyly)
  • Malar hypoplasia
  • Joint laxity 

Cardiovascular manifestations:

  • Thickened atrioventricular valves, valvular prolapse (mitral regurgitation) 
  • Aortic valve dysfunction due to aortic root aneurysm
  • Aortic dissection and rupture due to cystic medial necrosis of the aorta

Ocular manifestations:

  • ectopia lentis
  • myopia
  • flat cornea
  • retinal detachments
  • early cataracts and glaucoma

Other systemic manifestations: 

  • thoracic scoliosis
  • spontaneous pneumothorax
  • striae atrophicae in the skin

Image (a) shows Walker-Murdoch (wrist) sign - the ability to join the thumb and fifth finger around the wrist. Image (b) shows Steinberg (thumb) sign - thumb tip extends from the palm of the hand in a closed fist 

 

Diagnosis is based on criteria depending on the family history, aortic root X score, ectopia lentis, mitral valve prolapse, and presence of FBN1 mutation.

Other options:

Option B: Ehler Danlos syndrome is characterized by hyperextensible skin and hypermobile joints. However, the wrist sign is not a characteristic of EDS.

Option C: Osteogenesis imperfecta is characterized by a decrease in bone mineral density. Hence, the bones are very fragile limiting the physical activity of the patient.

Option D: Pseudoxanthoma elasticum is characterized by abnormal deposition of calcium in the elastic fibers of skin, eyes, and vessels.

questions.text: Blackfoot disease as shown in the image below is associated with chronic poisoning by:
questions.solution:
The image above shows keratosis of the palms and blackfoot disease in a woman. These features are seen in chronic arsenic poisoning.

Blackfoot disease is a gangrenous condition affecting the limbs. This was especially seen in diabetic patients consuming water contaminated with arsenic for long durations. It occurs due to the hypercoagulability of blood in peripheral arteries.

questions.text: The pinna develops from:
questions.solution:
Pinna develops both from the 1st and 2nd branchial arch. 

The development of the pinna begins from 6 weeks of embryonic life. A series of 6 tubercles are formed from the branchial arches which fuse to form the pinna. The tragus develops from the tubercle of the first arch while the rest of the pinna develops from the remaining five tubercles of the second arch. The external auditory canal develops from the first branchial cleft. 

Around 20 weeks of fetal life, the pinna attains adult shape. Initially, the pinna lies at the side of the neck but later attains a cranial position. Faulty fusion in the tubercles of two arches causes a preauricular cyst.

The below image shows the parts of the pinna. 

Related Pearl: Embryology of the ear

Structures of the ear Embryological origin
Auricle or pinna 1st and 2nd pharyngeal arch
External auditory meatus 1st pharyngeal arch
Tympanic membrane All 3 germ layers
Malleus and incus 1st pharyngeal arch
Stapes suprastructure 2nd pharyngeal arch
Stapes footplate and annular ligament Otic capsule
Tympanic cavity 1st pharyngeal pouch
Eustachian tube 1st pharyngeal pouch
Membranous labyrinth Otic vesicle
Semicircular canals and utricle Pars superior
Saccule and cochlea Pars inferior

Related Pearl: Congenital anomalies of pinna

Condition

Abnormality

Microtia

Small pinna

Anotia

Absent pinna and stenosis of outer EAC

Bat ear

Absent anti-helix

Mozart ear

Fusion of helix & antihelix

Wildermuth ear

Absent helix

Macrotia

Large pinna

questions.text: The finding in the below-given image is seen in a case of:
questions.solution:
The image findings show Hollenhorst plaques are seen in central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO).

They are the cholesterol emboli seen in retinal arterioles. The most common cause of CRAO (Central retinal artery occlusion) is embolism.

The outer retina is supplied by the ciliary arteries while the inner retina is supplied by the central retinal artery (CRA). Both sets of arteries are branches of the ophthalmic artery. Arterial occlusion can occur due to atherosclerosis (most cases), inflammation, vasospasm, and hypotension.

The ophthalmic artery is the first branch of the internal carotid artery, so any emboli from the carotid arteries can lead to CRAO. 

The emboli that are refractile, yellow-white in color, and made of cholesterol are called Hollenhorst plaques. Emboli can also be greyish, elongated fibrin-platelet aggregates, or non-scintillating white calcific particles. 

The goal of treatment is to restore blood flow. Antiplatelet therapy, decreasing intraocular pressure with timolol, acetazolamide and mannitol, and thrombolytic can be used. Rebreathing into a paper bag will help increase CO2 and consequently arterial vasodilation. 

Other options: 

Option B - Central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO) would have fundoscopy features of deep blot and flame-shaped hemorrhages in the posterior and peripheral retina and cotton wool spots.

The below image shows flame-shaped hemorrhages in CRVO.

 Option C - Cystoid macular edema occurs when there is fluid accumulation in the outer plexiform and inner nuclear layers of the retina with cyst-like cavities. It would have fundoscopy features of loss of foveal depression, thickening of the retina, and multiple cystoid areas in the sensory retina. There may be optic disc swelling and a lamellar hole. 

Option D - Central serous retinopathy is characterized by localized serous detachment of the retina at the macula due to leakage from the choriocapillaris. Detachment would be visible on fundoscopy with clear or turbid subretinal fluid, depigment retinal pigment epithelium, and atrophic damage.

questions.text: Spaghetti and meatballs appearance in KOH as shown here is characteristic of?
questions.solution:
Microscopy using KOH in Pityriasis versicolor shows hyphae and yeast cells that resemble spaghetti and meatballs.

Pityriasis versicolor:

  • Wood lamp examination - yellow-green fluorescence
  • Fungal culture -  usually reported to be negative
  • Skin biopsy - Fungal elements may be seen within the outer cells of the skin (stratum corneum) on histopathology.

questions.text: Muscle marked by black arrow in the given image, which forms lower boundary of quadrangular space is
questions.solution:
Teres major forms the lower boundary of quadrangular space.

Quadrangular space (Foramen of Velpeau):

Formed by:

  • Anteriorly: Subscapularis
  • Superiorly: Capsule of Shoulder joint, Teres Minor
  • Inferiorly: Teres Major
  • Medially: Long head of Triceps
  • Laterally: Surgical Neck of Humerus

Content:

  • Axillary nerve
  • Posterior circumflex humeral artery and vein

QS: Quadrangular space

TS: Triangular space

TI: Triangular interval

questions.text: The below given image depicts
questions.solution:
This image depicts Pinard’s maneuver used for delivery of extended legs in case of breech delivery.

Technique:

  • Flexion and abduction of popliteal fossa
  • Catch hold the ankle
  • Pull down by movement of abduction

Option a: Burns-Marshall method is used for delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Baby is allowed to hang by its own weight
  • When the nape of neck is visible under the pubic arch, baby is grasped by the ankles with finger in between the two
  • Baby is swung in an arc in an upward and forward direction

Option b: Modified Mauriceau-Smellie-Veit technique is used in the delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation.

Technique: Malar flexion and shoulder traction

  • Baby placed on supinated left forearm with arms hanging by the side.
  • Middle and index finger of left hand placed over baby’s malar bones to maintain flexion of head.
  • Pronated right hand – little and ring finger over baby’s right shoulder, middle finger over suboccipital region and index finger is placed on the left shoulder.
  • Traction is exerted in downward and backward direction and then in upward and forward direction once nape of neck is visible.

Option c: Lovset’s maneuver – Used for delivery of extended arms in case of breech presentation.

questions.text: The histological features seen in the image below are consistent with a diagnosis of ________.
questions.solution:
The histological features seen in the image below are consistent with a diagnosis of psoriasis.

Histopathological features of psoriasis:

  • Irregular epidermal thickening (acanthosis)
  • Hyperkeratosis and parakeratosis
  • Suprapapillary thinning
  • Clubbing of rete ridges at the base
  • Kogoj spongiform pustules (collection of neutrophils in the malpighian layer)
  • Munro microabscesses (collection of neutrophils in stratum corneum)
  • Absence of stratum granulosum
  • Dilated, tortuous blood vessels in the dermis
  • Suprapapillary mononuclear leukocytic infiltrates

Remember:  M (Munro microabscess) is seen in P (Psoriasis), and P (Pautrier’s microabscess) is seen in M (mycosis fungoides).

questions.text: The hierarchy of needs as depicted in below given image was given by
questions.solution: Abraham Maslow's hierarchy of needs is a motivational theory in psychology which has a five-tier model of human needs, often depicted as hierarchical levels within a pyramid. Maslow stated that people are motivated to achieve certain needs and that some needs take precedence over others.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man has been experiencing worsening headaches and new-onset seizures. MRI with contrast was done and is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given MRI finding is suggestive of glioblastoma. Post-contrast MRI in the case of glioblastoma multiforme, demonstrates a large heterogeneous mass that crosses the corpus callosum into both frontal lobes. 

They have a preferential spreading along the condensed white matter tracts such as corticospinal tracts and corpus callosum and can give rise to the so-called butterfly glioma, to involve the contralateral hemisphere. The term butterfly refers to the symmetric wing-like extensions across the midline. 

There is also evidence of a previous left-sided craniotomy and biopsy tract down to the lesion.

Glioblastoma is the second most common adult primary intracranial neoplasm. It carries the worst prognosis (WHO grade IV).

questions.text: Identify the chromosomal abnormality associated with the below-depicted phenotype
questions.solution:
Prominent occiput, clenched fist with overlapping fingers, rocker-bottom feet are all features of Edward syndrome i.e. Trisomy 18.

Trisomy 18 - Edwards syndrome

Phenotype:

  • Low birth weight
  • Closed fists with index finger overlapping the 3rd digit and the 5th digit overlapping the 4th
  • Narrow hips with limited abduction
  • Short sternum
  • Rocker-bottom feet
  • Microcephaly
  • Prominent occiput
  • Micrognathia
  • Cardiac and renal malformations
  • Intellectual disability

questions.text: The below depicted sign is seen in which type of melanoma
questions.solution:
The image shows Hutchinsins's nail sign in a subungual melanoma , a variant of Acral lentiginous melanoma. 

Subungual melanoma, a variant of acral lentiginous melanoma, arises from the nail matrix, most commonly in the great toe or thumb

Hutchinson's nail sign is an important clinical clue to subungual melanoma and is characterized by extension of brown or black pigment from the nail bed, matrix, and nail plate to the adjacent cuticle and proximal or lateral nail folds. Also there is associated nail dystrophy.

Remember : 

Acral lentiginous melanoma is type of melanoma  arising on the palms or soles. It is characterised by its site of origin: palm, sole, or beneath the nail (subungual melanoma ).

Other Options : 

Superficial spreading:Form of melanoma in which the malignant cells tend to stay within the tissue of origin, the epidermis, in an ‘in situ ' phase for a prolonged period and then it  grows horizontally on the skin surface – this is known as the radial growth phase. The lesion presents as a slowly-enlarging flat area of discoloured skin.

 

 

 

Nodular melanoma : Here  malignant melanoma cells proliferate downwards through the skin – this is known as vertical growth.

 

 

Lentigo maligna melanoma:Lentigo maligna is an early form of melanoma in which the malignant cells are confined to the tissue of origin, the epidermis, hence it is often reported as 'in situ 'melanoma.

questions.text: All are true about the condition that is diagnosed by the given ECG except:

choices.text: Can be seen in asymptomatic individuals
Caused by an abnormal accessory pathway

questions.solution:
The given ECG is suggestive of Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome (WPW). Its prevalence decreases with age.

The classic ECG features in WPW are as follows:

  • A shortened PR interval (typically <120 ms)
  • A slurring and the slow rise of the initial upstroke of the QRS complex (delta wave)
  • A widened QRS complex (total duration >0.12 seconds)
  • ST-segment–T wave (repolarization) changes, generally directed opposite the major delta wave and QRS complex, reflecting altered depolarization

Related Pearl: Wolff Parkinson White Syndrome

Wolff Parkinson White Syndrome (WPW) is characterized by an abnormal accessory pathway in the heart leading to arrhythmias.

Pathology- Born with an accessory pathway, the bundle of Kent which connects the atria and ventricle. The electrical impulses from the SA node reach the ventricles earlier via the accessory pathway as there is no AV nodal delay in this pathway. This leads to the preexcitation of the ventricle and initiation of ventricular contraction. This ventricular contraction is prolonged when the impulse via the AV nodal pathway reaches the ventricles.

Most common location of the accessory pathway- between the left atrium and free wall of the left ventricle

ECG changes:

Shortened PR interval- because of the early initiation of ventricular depolarization

Prolonged QRS duration- because of the AV nodal impulse reaching the ventricles after the aberrant impulse.

Delta waves- slurred upstroke of QRS complex

The given ECG shows delta waves marked with red arrows:

Treatment:

  • Catheter ablation is the treatment of choice.
  • Anti-arrhythmic drugs like procainamide, amiodarone, quinidine, propafenone, dofetilide are used in slowing conduction in the accessory pathway (prolong refractory period).
  • IV procainamide is the drug of choice in a hemodynamically stable WPW presenting with atrial fibrillation.
  • DC cardioversion is done in hemodynamically unstable patients.

questions.text: Structure marked “?” in below given image is
questions.solution:
The image shows the floor of the third ventricle and structure marked “?” is mamillary body.

The mammillary bodies are pea-sized eminences anterior to the posterior perforated substance.

questions.text: Following sign is associated with which disorder
questions.solution: Image shows Russell’s sign which refers to calluses on hands from teeth scraping during self-induced vomiting in case of bulimia nervosa.

questions.text: Considering the following image, which of the following is true?

choices.text: Hysteroscopy is the preferred modality for making the diagnosis
HSG (hysterosalpingography) cannot differentiate between the bicornuate and septate uteri

questions.solution:
The given image shows HSG(hysterosalpingography). It can either be a bicornuate uterus or a septate uterus.

HSG provides excellent information about the interior contour of the uterine cavity, but not the external uterine contour, so it cannot distinguish between septate and bicornuate uteri.

Pelvic MRI without contrast provides excellent delineation of both internal and external uterine contours and can differentiate septate from bicornuate uteri.

Transvaginal 3-D ultrasonography (3D TV US) is very accurate for the diagnosis and differentiation between the septate uterus and bicornuate uterus.

3D TV US is recommended as the first and only mandatory step in the assessment of the uterine cavity in patients with a suspected septate or bicornuate uterus, especially before planning surgery.

MRI should be reserved for patients in whom 3D TVS is not possible like virgins.

Hysteroscopy cannot reliably differentiate between a septate and a bicornuate uterus unless a laparoscopy to view the uterine fundus is also performed.

 

In the images given below: A-Normal, B-Unicornuate, C-Arcuate, D to G-Septate uterus of different grades, H-Bicornuate, I-Didelphys

Related Pearl: Mullerian Anomalies

 

Class Mullerian anomaly Reason/Feature Treatment Complications
I Uterine hypoplasia or uterine agenesis Underdeveloped or non-developed paramesonephric duct
  • Infertility treatment -surrogacy 
  • Vaginoplasty for vaginal hypoplasia
 Infertility

 
II Unicornuate uterus Non-developed paramesonephric duct Excision of rudimentary horn, if any  
  • Uterine rupture
  • Abortions
  • Risk of miscarriage,
  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery
III Uterus didelphys Unfused paramesonephric duct

Metroplasty- Resection of membrane and fundal recombination. This can be:

  • Hysteroscopic
  • Open e.g., Strassman metroplasty
  • Risk of miscarriage,
  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery
IV Bicornuate uterus  Lower part is fused whereas upper part is unfused Metroplasty in selected cases 
  • Risk of miscarriage,
  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery
V Septate uterus  Septa of fused part persists Hysteroscopic septal resection 
  • Infertility
  • Risk of miscarriage,
  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery
VI Arcuate uterus A small indentation at upper part    
VII Diethylstillbesterone (DES), drug related T-shaped uterus, shortened and narrow fallopian tubes, cervical collars (Cockscomb cervix)  
  • Ectopic pregnancy
  • Cervical incompetence
  • Clear cell adenocarcinoma of cervix and vagina

A common complication is an abortion in the second trimester.

Arcuate uterus: Some studies report no increase in adverse outcomes, whereas some studies have shown excessive second trimester loss, preterm labor and malpresentations.

questions.text: Which of the following process doesn’t occur in below given organelle
questions.solution:
• Glycolysis is the principal route for carbohydrate metabolism. It takes place in the cytosol of all cells.
  • Ketogenesis, fatty acid oxidation and acetyl CoA production occurs in mitochondria.

questions.text: Interpret the given audiogram
questions.solution:
Interpretation:

  • Red indicates right ear
  • O indicates AC and threshold is >15 dB. Hence AC is abnormal
  • < indicates BC and threshold is >25 dB. Hence BC is abnormal
  • Both AC and BC are abnormal. It indicates sensorineural hearing loss
  • There is no Air-Bone gap
  • Hence it is right side sensorineural hearing loss

questions.text: You are investigating an outbreak of diarrhea.  You find out that the etiological agent causes stacked-brick formation on hep-2 cells as shown below.  What is the likely organism?
questions.solution:
The stacked-brick pattern of adherence on hep-2 cells is caused by enteroaggregative E. coli (EAEC).

Enteroaggregative E. coli has been associated with persistent diarrhea. Intestinal colonization of EAEC is mediated by aggregative adherence fimbriae (AAF). EAST-1 toxin (enteroaggregative heat-stable toxin) is considered to be a major virulence factor for EAEC.

The given image shows the stacked-brick pattern of adherence on microscopy at 600x magnification.

questions.text: Identify the chromosomal anomaly associated with below depicted histological type of renal cell carcinoma

choices.text: Deletion of short arm of chromosome 3

questions.solution:
Image shows classic vacuolated (lipid-laden) cells or clear cells of clear cell carcinoma.

It is the most common type and associated with deletion of short arm of chromosome 3 i.e. von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) disease.

Features of VHL syndrome:

  • Cerebellar hemangioblastoma
  • Bilateral renal cell carcinoma
  • Retinal angiomatosis
Type of renal cell carcinoma    Chromosomal abnormalities
Clear cell carcinoma Deletion of short arm of chromosome 3 (VHL gene)
Papillary carcinoma

Familial

  • Trisomy 7Sporadic
  • Trisomy 7, 16, 17
  • Loss of Y in males·
  • T(X;1)
Chromophobe carcinoma Hypodiploidy (Loss of multiple chromosomes 1,2,6,10,13,17,21,Y)

questions.text: The below given graph depicts effect of “X” on composition of pancreatic secretion. Identify “X”.
questions.solution:
The graph shows an increase in HCO3-, decrease in Cl- and amylase level after infusion of substance “X”. Hence it is secretin.

Secretion of pancreatic juice is primarily under hormonal control.

Secretin acts on the pancreatic ducts to cause copious secretion of a very alkaline pancreatic juice that is rich in HCO3− and poor in enzymes,  due to an increase in intracel­lular cAMP. The fall in amylase concentration reflects dilution as the volume of pancreatic juice increases. 

Related Pearl: Regulation of pancreatic secretion

(S cells)

↑HCO3- in secretion

(I cells)

Acinar cell

Phospholipase C (IP3/DAG)

↑ release of zymogen granules (enzymes)

Potentiates effect of secretin

ACh

(vagi)

Acinar cell

Phospholipase C (IP3/DAG)

↑ release of zymogen granules (enzymes)

Potentiates effect of secretin

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about the given dose-response curve?

choices.text: Drug B is the most potent.
Drug B is the most efficacious.
Drug C is more efficacious than drug D.
Drug A is more potent than drug B.

questions.solution:
The more the curve is on the left in a dose-response curve (DRC), the greater is its potency. Hence, Drug B is the most potent.

Potency:

  • It is defined as the amount of drug needed to produce a given response.
  • A highly potent drug evokes a given response at low concentrations and vice-versa.
  • In the above image, the potency is Drug B> Drug A > Drug C > Drug D.

Efficacy:

  • It is defined as the maximum effect produced by the drug. It reflects the capacity of the drug to activate a receptor and produce the response.
  • In the log dose-response curve, the perpendicular height represents the drug efficacy.
  • Thus, in the above image, the efficacy is Drug A = Drug C =Drug D > Drug B.
  • Drugs having a similar pharmacological effect can have different efficacies e.g furosemide and metolazone are both diuretics but furosemide has greater efficacy than metolazone.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is transmitted by the vector shown in the image given below?
questions.solution:
The vector shown in the image is a tsetse fly. It transmits African sleeping sickness (African human trypanosomiasis).

Tsetse flies belong to the genus Glossina. They have not demonstrated insecticide resistance. Methods of tsetse fly control include spraying of DDT, clearing of vegetation, destruction of wild game and genetic control.

Related Pearl: Arthropod- borne diseases

Arthropod Disease transmitted
Anopheles mosquito Malaria, Filariasis

Aedes mosquito Yellow fever, Dengue, Chikungunya, filariasis, zika
Mansoni Mosquito Filariasis, Chikungunya
Housefly Typhoid and paratyphoid fever, diarrhea, dysentery, cholera, gastroenteritis, amoebiasis, helminthic infestations, poliomyelitis, conjunctivitis, trachoma, anthrax, yaws, etc.
Sandfly (Phlebotomus) Kala-azar(Visceral Leishmaniasis), oriental sore, Oroya fever, Sandfly fever
Tsetse fly Sleeping sickness(African Trypanosomiasis)
Louse Epidemic typhus, relapsing fever, trench fever, pediculosis
Rat flea Bubonic plague, endemic typhus(Murine Typhus), hymenolepis diminuta
Black fly(Simulium) Onchocerciasis
Reduviid bug(Kissing bug/triatominae) Chagas disease(American Trypanosomiasis)
Hard tick (Ixodes species) Tick typhus, viral encephalitis, viral fevers, viral hemorrhagic fever,(e.g. Kyasanur forest disease), tularemia, tick paralysis, human babesiosis, lyme disease
Soft Tick (Argas species) Q fever, relapsing fever, Kyasanur forest disease (KFD) (can be casued by hard tick as well)
Trombiculid mite Scrub typhus, Rickettsial pox
Itch mites Scabies
Cyclops Guinea-worm disease, fish tapeworm (D. latum)
Cockroaches Enteric pathogens
Sand flea (Tunga penetrance, Jiggar, Chigoe flea)  Tungiasis, Ulcer in the feetnails

questions.text: A patient posted for surgery is taken inside the OT. You observe the following capnograph as the anesthetist starts the procedure. When is this pattern observed?
questions.solution:
The pattern is observed when the anesthetist commences the tracheal intubation of the patient. Tracheal intubation resembles a normal capnogram during controlled mechanical ventilation. 

A capnograph is a simple device that records and shows the concentration of carbon dioxide as a function of time. It describes both the inspiratory and expiratory phases. Phase 0 refers to the inspiratory segment while there are usually three phases during expiration. They are:

  • Phase I is the end of inspiration and the beginning of expiration. It correlates to the expired dead space gas from the central conducting airways or from any equipment distal to the site of sampling. In this phase, the partial pressure of carbon dioxide is zero and thus there is no detectable CO2.
  • Phase II is characterized by a sharp rise in the partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PCO2). This is due to the exchange of gases between the conducting airway and alveoli. 
  • Phase III has a plateau component (no rise in PCO2) which depicts the partial pressure of carbon dioxide in the alveoli. It is flat throughout expiration in a homogeneously ventilated lung. 

 The below image shows normal capnography.

Other options:

Option A: In esophageal intubation, the capnograph remains flat or shows small abnormal waveforms which get diminished in height in the following 2 or 3 cycles till they are lost. It can be seen when the endotracheal tube is incorrectly placed. It is shown below.

 

Option B: In rebreathing, the fraction of inspired CO2 is above zero while the shape of the capnograph is preserved with one exception. EtCO2 rises as a consequence. 

Option D: Malignant hyperthermia is characterized by hypoventilation. In this, there is a rise in ETCO2 while the shape is otherwise preserved.

Related Pearl: Various capnography waveforms:

A- Obstructive airway or bronchospasm
B- Expiratory valve malfunctioning
C- Inspiratory valve malfunction
D- Normal physiological variant seen in pregnant subjects under GA
E- Curare cleft
F- Rebreathing
G- Esophageal intubation
H- Spontaneous breathing
I-Dual capnogram in one lung transplantation patient. The first peak in phase III is from the transplanted normal lung, whereas the second peak is from the native disease lung. A variation of dual capnogram (steeple sign capnogram – dotted line) is seen if there is a leak around the sidestream sensor port at the monitor
J- Malignant hyperthermia
K- Classic ripple effect during the expiratory pause showing cardiogenic oscillations
L- Sudden rise of baseline and end-tidal PCO2 (PETCO2) due to contamination of the sensor with secretions or water vapor.
The gradual rise of baseline and PETCO2 occurs when soda lime is exhausted. 
M -Intermittent mechanical ventilation (IMV) breaths in the midst of spontaneously breathing patient.
N -Cardiopulmonary resuscitation: capnogram showing positive waveforms during each compression. 
O-Capnogram showing rebreathing during inspiration. This is normal in rebreathing circuits such as Mapleson D or Bain circuit.
